ticket.title: Print controller module into request log
ticket.original-body:
Currently ActionController request log contains only controller class name, without module, like > Processing UsersController#index ...
When you put half of you controllers in modules, like UsersController and Admin::UsersController, then the absence of module in the log becames a problem. Mostly for log analysis tools, and for situations when you encounter some routing bugs and can't undersand what controller processed the request.
So I think it would be better to have such output: > Processing Admin::UsersController#index ...
So there is a patch to fix it.

When you put half of you controllers in modules, like UsersController and Admin::UsersController, then the absence of module in the log becames a problem. Mostly for log analysis tools, and for situations when you encounter some routing bugs and can't undersand what controller processed the request.
So I think it would be better to have such output: > Processing Admin::UsersController#index ...
So there is a patch to fix it.
ticket.original-body-html:
Currently ActionController request log contains only controller class name, without module, like

Processing UsersController#index ...

When you put half of you controllers in modules, like UsersController and Admin::UsersController, then the absence of module in the log becames a problem. Mostly for log analysis tools, and for situations when you encounter some routing bugs and can't undersand what controller processed the request.

So I think it would be better to have such output:

Processing Admin::UsersController#index ...

So there is a patch to fix it.

version.body-html:
Currently ActionController request log contains only controller class name, without module, like

Processing UsersController#index ...

When you put half of you controllers in modules, like UsersController and Admin::UsersController, then the absence of module in the log becames a problem. Mostly for log analysis tools, and for situations when you encounter some routing bugs and can't undersand what controller processed the request.

So I think it would be better to have such output:

So there is a patch to fix it.
version.title: Print controller module into request log

version.body: +1 from me. It passes the tests and makes total sense.
version.body-html: +1 from me. It passes the tests and makes total sense.
version.title: Print controller module into request log

version.body:
Little note: A single test fails -> 1) Failure: test_action_cache_conditional_options(ActionCacheTest) [./test/controller/caching_test.rb:290:in `test_action_cache_conditional_options' ./test/../lib/../../activesupport/lib/active_support/testing/setup_and_teardown.rb:91:in `__send__' ./test/../lib/../../activesupport/lib/active_support/testing/setup_and_teardown.rb:91:in `run']: <false> is not true.
But this also fails w/o the patch so I don't think it's related.
version.body-html:
Little note: A single test fails ->

1) Failure:

test_action_cache_conditional_options(ActionCacheTest)

[./test/controller/caching_test.rb:290:in `test_action_cache_conditional_options'

./test/../lib/../../activesupport/lib/active_support/testing/setup_and_teardown.rb:91:in `__send__'

./test/../lib/../../activesupport/lib/active_support/testing/setup_and_teardown.rb:91:in `run']:

is not true.

But this also fails w/o the patch so I don't think it's related.
version.title: Print controller module into request log

version.body: +1. Attaching a patch with passing test.
version.body-html: +1. Attaching a patch with passing test.
version.title: Print controller module into request log

version.body:
(from [f7fdbae770275ccbc277c42287b9783cb00fa9fa]) Use fully-qualified controller name when logging. [#600 state:resolved]
Signed-off-by: Pratik Naik <pratiknaik@gmail.com> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/f7fdbae770275ccbc277c42287b9783cb00fa9fa
